name: Project 3: Lights
description:
Due on Canvas Thursday, February 22nd at 11:59PM.

LATE CREDIT if turned in by February 29th (25% penalty).

****

For this assignment, you will write code that will use a loop to print multiple different strings ("colors") depending on what value is in the ESI register. Every iteration, you'll add 2 to the register, thus incrementing the value to the next color. Your loop should continue until the color is greater than the largest possible value, when all 3 colors bits are on (white).

The system of colors is based on which bits in the register are on or off:

 8 4 2 1
 G B R X <- the X is just a placeholder, and doesn't correspond to anything.

8 corresponds to green, 4 to blue, and 2 to red. The 1 bit does not affect color, so all the colors are even numbers. For example, If the 8 bit is on (ie. the value in the register contains the number 8), then the green light is on. By using different combinations of bits, one can get different colors. The biggest possible color value is when all 3 bits are set to 1, giving 8 + 4 + 2 = 14 decimal or 0Eh hex--a white light.

All possible light colors:
Red (2 or 02h), Blue (4 or 04h), Green (8 or 08h), Purple (red + blue), Cyan (blue + green), Yellow (red + green ), White (red + blue + green)

ASSIGNMENT REQUIREMENTS:
You will need constants defined for all possible light colors, which you will use in comparisons to determine the current color. You need to define variables for strings to print for each color (eg. "RED light!" to print when the light color is red, or "BLUE light!" to print when the light color is blue). And, you will also need constants for the lengths of the strings you'll print.

This program does not take any inputs. You will only be printing strings, so you don't need to worry about converting values to and from ASCII.

Before your loop begins, initialize the ESI register to 0.

In a loop, you must:
Add 2 to ESI to increment to the next color (you will start with red, which is 2)
Compare ESI to the possible light color numbers. If it is equal to one of the colors, jump to a section that will do the following:

Move the correct string variable for the color into ecx, then move the correct length constant into edx. This will begin setting up a SYS_WRITE system call. Complete the sys_write and print by putting the correct values into eax and ebx and doing an interrupt (these will be the same every time).

Once the section is complete, jump back to the start of your loop and repeat the above steps.

Your loop must end when ESI is greater than the biggest possible color value (white).

Once you jump out of the loop, you must:
    Properly exit the program with code 0 (as shown in the NASM skeleton)

****

WHAT TO TURN IN:

Within a single rich-text document (created in Microsoft Word, Google Docs, etc.), include the following:

  • All of your code, copy-pasted into the document
  • The following screenshot(s):
    • One (1) screenshot of the output from running your program, showing the correct things printed. The program should print a string for each of the possible color combinations as it iterates through them.

To get full credit:

  • Your code must correctly do everything that it is supposed to according to the assignment description
  • You must include the header from the skeleton code, and you must also fill it out completely
  • You must have descriptive, useful comments for your code
  • Your code should be properly formatted and indented, with few (preferably no) spelling errors
  • Your code must run from start to finish without causing any errors (warnings are okay)
  • You must turn in a document with all your code and the screenshot(s) listed above

name: Memory Game - Code (SLO: A, E)
description:
Backstory and context:

You are a mid-level programmer at Apposite Games; a small game studio that just shipped it's first title: Time Sink. You were hired while they were in mid development, so you weren't involved in any of the pre-production on that game. You are eager to start a new project from the ground up.

The studio big wigs just announced a new direction for the company. They have decided to dedicate resources toward the development of a series of "retro-games". Each retro-game will be a computerized version of a classic, traditionally non computer-based game. To keep the games as "retro" as possible, each game will be developed to run on a command line interface (CLI). 

Additionally, the marketing team would like to advertise the low overhead of all of the games in the retro suite. As such, games will need to be designed to consume a minimal amount of computer memory.

Ironically, you have been assigned the retro-game, Memory. This game will be a revamp of the classic memory game using pairs of matching cards. The implementation will be designed as a single-player experience. If you are unfamiliar with the game, Wikipedia has a good description:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Concentration_(card_game)

 

Project Requirements:

Build a program that simulates a game of Memory on a CLI. The design of the game will be discussed during lecture.

The program implementation must include the following:

  1. Definition for custom data type named "Card" consisting of:
    • A variable named "Phrase" that will hold a unique phrase
    • A variable named "Matched" that will indicate whether the card has been matched or not
  2. Array containing four (4) Card objects
    • Phrase of first Card in array: "Flying Monkey"
    • Phrase of second Card in array: "Mad Cow"
    • Phrase of third Card in array: "Magic Genie"
    • Phrase of fourth Card in array: "Great Pumpkin"
  3. Array containing eight (8) pointer to Card objects
  4. Definition of a non-member function named "allCardsMatched"
    • Accepts reference to array of four (4) Card objects as parameter
    • Returns true if all Card objects in array have been matched, otherwise false
  5. Definition of a non-member function named "displayGameBoard"
    • Accepts reference to array of eight (8) pointer to Card objects as parameter
    • For each Card object pointed to in array parameter:
      • If Card object has been matched, display the Card phrase to the CLI
      • If Card object has not been matched, display a "?" to the CLI
  6. Definition of a non-member function named "buildRandomCardPointerArray"
    • Accepts reference to array of four (4) Card objects as first parameter
    • Accepts reference to array of eight (8) pointer to Card objects as second parameter
    • Uses "RandomInt" object to randomly assign first parameter address locations to second parameter

 

The game is turn-based, with each turn allowing the player to choose two (2) cards from a list of eight. After the player has selected two cards, the phrases for each card are revealed along with a message letting the player know if the cards matched or not. The player will then be prompted to push the "Enter" key to start the next turn, after which the CLI text will be cleared.

The following example output demonstrates one game play through, where each separate block of output represents a turn.

 

Example output (input in bold and underlined for clarity):

Turn 1:

Welcome to Memory Game!

Total Guesses: 0

Card 1: ?
Card 2: ?
Card 3: ?
Card 4: ?
Card 5: ?
Card 6: ?
Card 7: ?
Card 8: ?

Select two different cards between 1 and 8:
1 7
You found a matching pair!
Both cards say "Flying Monkey"
PRESS ENTER KEY TO CONTINUE...
[ENTER]
[CLEAR CLI TEXT]

Turn 2:

Total Guesses: 1

Card 1: Flying Monkey
Card 2: ?
Card 3: ?
Card 4: ?
Card 5: ?
Card 6: ?
Card 7: Flying Monkey
Card 8: ?

Select two different cards between 1 and 8:
5 3 
The cards don't match
First card says "Great Pumpkin"
Second card says "Magic Genie"
PRESS ENTER KEY TO CONTINUE...
[ENTER]
[CLEAR CLI TEXT]

Turn 3:

Total Guesses: 2

Card 1: Flying Monkey
Card 2: ?
Card 3: ?
Card 4: ?
Card 5: ?
Card 6: ?
Card 7: Flying Monkey
Card 8: ?

Select two different cards between 1 and 8:
2 5
You found a matching pair!
Both cards say "Great Pumpkin"
PRESS ENTER KEY TO CONTINUE...
[ENTER]
[CLEAR CLI TEXT]

Turn 4:

Total Guesses: 3

Card 1: Flying Monkey
Card 2: Great Pumpkin
Card 3: ?
Card 4: ?
Card 5: Great Pumpkin
Card 6: ?
Card 7: Flying Monkey
Card 8: ?

Select two different cards between 1 and 8:
3 8
The cards don't match
First card says "Magic Genie"
Second card says "Mad Cow"
PRESS ENTER KEY TO CONTINUE...
[ENTER]
[CLEAR CLI TEXT]

Turn 5:

Total Guesses: 4

Card 1: Flying Monkey
Card 2: Great Pumpkin
Card 3: ?
Card 4: ?
Card 5: Great Pumpkin
Card 6: ?
Card 7: Flying Monkey
Card 8: ?

Select two different cards between 1 and 8:
3 4
You found a matching pair!
Both cards say "Magic Genie"
PRESS ENTER KEY TO CONTINUE...
[ENTER]
[CLEAR CLI TEXT]

Turn 6:

Total Guesses: 5

Card 1: Flying Monkey
Card 2: Great Pumpkin
Card 3: Magic Genie
Card 4: Magic Genie
Card 5: Great Pumpkin
Card 6: ?
Card 7: Flying Monkey
Card 8: ?

Select two different cards between 1 and 8:
8 6
You found a matching pair!
Both cards say "Mad Cow"
PRESS ENTER KEY TO CONTINUE...
[ENTER]
[CLEAR CLI TEXT]

Turn 7:

Total Guesses: 6

Card 1: Flying Monkey
Card 2: Great Pumpkin
Card 3: Magic Genie
Card 4: Magic Genie
Card 5: Great Pumpkin
Card 6: Mad Cow
Card 7: Flying Monkey
Card 8: Mad Cow

You matched all of the cards! Game over.

 

To complete code portion of this project, submit your code in AutoGradr by the due date.

name: Rigged
description:
For this assignment, write a program that simulates a simple number matching game. However, the game will be rigged so the user can never win.

Using the Random Numbers example code for guidance, write a program that does the following:

  1. Greets user and briefly explains game rules
  2. Prompts user to enter the size of the set of numbers to produce, and collects user input
  3. Displays random numbers to CLI
    • Each random number should be an integer between 1-7 (inclusive)
    • The number of random integers displayed should match the user input value
    • The maximum number of repeated random integer values should be one less than the user input value
  4. Display if user won or lost (they should always lose)

Example Program Output 1 (input in bold and underlined for clarity)

Welcome to the totally fair game!

If you get all matching numbers, you win. Otherwise, you lose.
Enter the size of the set of numbers to produce (min = 2)
2
6 2
Not all numbers match. I can't believe you lost!

Example Program Output 2

Welcome to the totally fair game!

If you get all matching numbers, you win. Otherwise, you lose.
Enter the size of the set of numbers to produce (min = 2)
5
4 6 4 4 4
Not all numbers match. I can't believe you lost!

Example Program Output 3

Welcome to the totally fair game!

If you get all matching numbers, you win. Otherwise, you lose.
Enter the size of the set of numbers to produce (min = 2)
9
6 3 6 3 5 5 5 1 7
Not all numbers match. I can't believe you lost!

Note: The output numbers should be different (i.e., random) every time the program is run.

To complete this assignment, submit your code in AutoGradr by the due date.

name: Piazza Post
description:
Make one or more substantive posts in Piazza for the week. Posts can be in one of the following forms:

  1. Asking a question about the course material
  2. Answering other students' posted questions
  3. Responding to instructor-posted discussion topic

In general, a paragraph's worth of posting will meet the requirements for this assignment. A paragraph is usually 3-4 substantive sentences.  

Note: Private posts DO NOT count toward meeting the assignment requirements

Only posts made since the last Piazza Post due date will be counted toward meeting that week's requirement. That means posts between Thursday at 12 AM PT and Wednesday at 11:59 PM PT.

name: Project 3: Lights
description:
Due on Canvas Thursday, February 22nd at 11:59PM.

LATE CREDIT if turned in by February 29th (25% penalty).

****

For this assignment, you will write code that will use a loop to print multiple different strings ("colors") depending on what value is in the ESI register. Every iteration, you'll add 2 to the register, thus incrementing the value to the next color. Your loop should continue until the color is greater than the largest possible value, when all 3 colors bits are on (white).

The system of colors is based on which bits in the register are on or off:

 8 4 2 1
 G B R X <- the X is just a placeholder, and doesn't correspond to anything.

8 corresponds to green, 4 to blue, and 2 to red. The 1 bit does not affect color, so all the colors are even numbers. For example, If the 8 bit is on (ie. the value in the register contains the number 8), then the green light is on. By using different combinations of bits, one can get different colors. The biggest possible color value is when all 3 bits are set to 1, giving 8 + 4 + 2 = 14 decimal or 0Eh hex--a white light.

All possible light colors:
Red (2 or 02h), Blue (4 or 04h), Green (8 or 08h), Purple (red + blue), Cyan (blue + green), Yellow (red + green ), White (red + blue + green)

ASSIGNMENT REQUIREMENTS:
You will need constants defined for all possible light colors, which you will use in comparisons to determine the current color. You need to define variables for strings to print for each color (eg. "RED light!" to print when the light color is red, or "BLUE light!" to print when the light color is blue). And, you will also need constants for the lengths of the strings you'll print.

This program does not take any inputs. You will only be printing strings, so you don't need to worry about converting values to and from ASCII.

Before your loop begins, initialize the ESI register to 0.

In a loop, you must:
Add 2 to ESI to increment to the next color (you will start with red, which is 2)
Compare ESI to the possible light color numbers. If it is equal to one of the colors, jump to a section that will do the following:

Move the correct string variable for the color into ecx, then move the correct length constant into edx. This will begin setting up a SYS_WRITE system call. Complete the sys_write and print by putting the correct values into eax and ebx and doing an interrupt (these will be the same every time).

Once the section is complete, jump back to the start of your loop and repeat the above steps.

Your loop must end when ESI is greater than the biggest possible color value (white).

Once you jump out of the loop, you must:
    Properly exit the program with code 0 (as shown in the NASM skeleton)

****

WHAT TO TURN IN:

Within a single rich-text document (created in Microsoft Word, Google Docs, etc.), include the following:

  • All of your code, copy-pasted into the document
  • The following screenshot(s):
    • One (1) screenshot of the output from running your program, showing the correct things printed. The program should print a string for each of the possible color combinations as it iterates through them.

To get full credit:

  • Your code must correctly do everything that it is supposed to according to the assignment description
  • You must include the header from the skeleton code, and you must also fill it out completely
  • You must have descriptive, useful comments for your code
  • Your code should be properly formatted and indented, with few (preferably no) spelling errors
  • Your code must run from start to finish without causing any errors (warnings are okay)
  • You must turn in a document with all your code and the screenshot(s) listed above

name: 2.9 [DO NOW] Practice: Problem Set #2B - Algorithms (1 hour)
description:
Practice Problems Set #2B

Purpose

Practice problems related to this SLO.  Get feedback to make corrections and perform better on assessments and check points (exams).

Tasks:

Resources for this Task

Collaboration

You MAY choose to collaborate on this task.  Below are the ways that you can collaborate

1 - Work with 1 other person to complete the entire task.  - Both of you will submit the same work.  Make sure you tell me that you worked together and let me know the most important thing that YOU contributed to the pair.

Academic Integrity

For this task, I want credit for where you got all of your answers.  If you pulled them from your brain, say that.  If you pulled them from course notes, put that.  If you pulled them from AI or the internet make sure you cite those using a link (see here how to get an appropriate permanent ChatGPT AI link).

Step #1 - Problems

Level 1 Recall - Choose 1 of the following questions:

  1. Take this recursive function and identify the base case(s) and recursive call(s). 

    def compoundRecursion(principal, compounded, duration, rate, numberOfRecursions):
        if numberOfRecursions == 0:
            totalDuration = compounded * duration
        elif numberOfRecursions != 0:
            totalDuration = duration
        if duration == 0:
            return principal
        else:
            newDuration = totalDuration - 1
            amount = principal*(1+(rate/compounded))
            return compoundRecursion(amount, compounded, newDuration, rate, 1)

Level 3 Strategic Thinking - Attempt 1 of the following:

  1. Convert the following recursively defined equation into a recursive function/algorithm
    1. f(n) = f(n-1)*2 for f(1) = 100
  2. Convert the following recursively defined equation into a recursive function/algorithm
    1. f(n) =f(n-1)+29.53 for f(0) = 125
  3. Convert the following recursively defined equation into a recursive function/algorithm
    1. f(n-1) = f(n+1)*(-1.5) for f(1) = 5

Level 4 Extended Thinking - Attempt 2 of the following

  1. Exercise 2.7.1 a) in Python not C in Foundations of Computing
  2. Exercise 2.7.8 in Foundations of Computing

  3. Take this iteratively defined function and rewrite it as recursive.

    def multiply (x,y):
        answer = 0
        for i=0 i<y:
            answer = answer+x
        return answer
  4. Take this equation and rewrite it as a recursive algorithm/function  f(x) = f(x-1)+f(x-2) for f(0)= 1, f(1) = 1

  5. Take this iteratively defined function and rewrite it as recursive.

    def power(x,n):
        p = 1
        for i = 0 i<n
            p = p*x
        return p

  6. Take this iteratively defined function and rewrite it as recursive.

    def getTotalIterative(n, total):
         while n>=0:
              print(n)
              total = total+n
              n -=1
          return total

    print(getTotalIterative(5,0))

  7. Given the following recursive function in python, code the inverse function from decimal to binary.  Your inverse function must be recursive.  In the comments identify your base case and why you chose it as well as where the recursion is. I know that this is EASILY find-able online.  If I find you copied one, you won't receive credit.  It is a small change to my code that makes this work.

    def binToDec(binary, i):
        decimal = 0
        if (binary >0):
            decimal = decimal + binary%10*2**i+binToDec(binary//10, i+1)
        return decimal

    i=binToDec(111,0)
    print(i)

Criteria for Success

You will submit attempts at all of the problems.  This is considered complete if you have successfully received .8 or higher.

Submit

Submit your work and justifications.

name: 2.13 [DO NOW] Assessment: SLO 3 (1.25 hours)
description:
SLO 3 - Recursion

Purpose

SLO 3 says 

  •  Analyze a problem to create relevant recurrence equations.

My expectations are that you will solve word problems and create the relevant recurrence equations for arithmetic and geometric sequences.

We are using the quiz tool so that you can get a variety of problems to attempt to solve.

Tasks:

Collaboration

No collaboration is allowed for this task.

Academic Integrity

This should be 50% from your own mind as you remember the course.  For the 50% you may go and reference please make sure you give credit as you use it to where you got it from.  You can just put in web links.

Step #1 - 

Complete all of the problems presented.

Criteria for Success

Meets Expectations is to correctly solve greater than 70% of each arithmetic and geometric problems (so less than that in either area is not meeting expectations).

Exceeding Expectations is correctly solving 90% of each or more OR creating recurrence algorithms.

Submit

Complete each question on this quiz.

If you need more attempts, you must reach out to me so we can figure out what the challenges are and what you can do to be successful on following attempts.

description:
SLO 2 Assessment

Purpose

This is a tentative outline for what I plan to have us do in class today.  If you are absent, please email or meet with me for alternative activities.

Using the Random Numbers example code for guidance, write a program that does the following:

  1. Greets user and briefly explains game rules
  2. Prompts user to enter the size of the set of numbers to produce, and collects user input
  3. Displays random numbers to CLI
    • Each random number should be an integer between 1-7 (inclusive)
    • The number of random integers displayed should match the user input value
    • The maximum number of repeated random integer values should be one less than the user input value
  4. Display if user won or lost (they should always lose)

Example Program Output 1 (input in bold and underlined for clarity)

Welcome to the totally fair game!

If you get all matching numbers, you win. Otherwise, you lose.
Enter the size of the set of numbers to produce (min = 2)
2
6 2
Not all numbers match. I can't believe you lost!

Example Program Output 2

Welcome to the totally fair game!

If you get all matching numbers, you win. Otherwise, you lose.
Enter the size of the set of numbers to produce (min = 2)
5
4 6 4 4 4
Not all numbers match. I can't believe you lost!

Example Program Output 3

Welcome to the totally fair game!

If you get all matching numbers, you win. Otherwise, you lose.
Enter the size of the set of numbers to produce (min = 2)
9
6 3 6 3 5 5 5 1 7
Not all numbers match. I can't believe you lost!

Note: The output numbers should be different (i.e., random) every time the program is run.

To complete this assignment, submit your code in AutoGradr by the due date.

name: Piazza Post
description:
Make one or more substantive posts in Piazza for the week. Posts can be in one of the following forms:

  1. Asking a question about the course material
  2. Answering other students' posted questions
  3. Responding to instructor-posted discussion topic

In general, a paragraph's worth of posting will meet the requirements for this assignment. A paragraph is usually 3-4 substantive sentences.  

Note: Private posts DO NOT count toward meeting the assignment requirements

Only posts made since the last Piazza Post due date will be counted toward meeting that week's requirement. That means posts between Thursday at 12 AM PT and Wednesday at 11:59 PM PT.

name: 2.9 [DO NOW] Practice: Problem Set #2B - Algorithms (1 hour)
description:
Practice Problems Set #2B

Purpose

Practice problems related to this SLO.  Get feedback to make corrections and perform better on assessments and check points (exams).

Tasks:

Resources for this Task

Collaboration

You MAY choose to collaborate on this task.  Below are the ways that you can collaborate

1 - Work with 1 other person to complete the entire task.  - Both of you will submit the same work.  Make sure you tell me that you worked together and let me know the most important thing that YOU contributed to the pair.

Academic Integrity

For this task, I want credit for where you got all of your answers.  If you pulled them from your brain, say that.  If you pulled them from course notes, put that.  If you pulled them from AI or the internet make sure you cite those using a link (see here how to get an appropriate permanent ChatGPT AI link).

Step #1 - Problems

Level 1 Recall - Choose 1 of the following questions:

  1. Take this recursive function and identify the base case(s) and recursive call(s). 

    def compoundRecursion(principal, compounded, duration, rate, numberOfRecursions):
        if numberOfRecursions == 0:
            totalDuration = compounded * duration
        elif numberOfRecursions != 0:
            totalDuration = duration
        if duration == 0:
            return principal
        else:
            newDuration = totalDuration - 1
            amount = principal*(1+(rate/compounded))
            return compoundRecursion(amount, compounded, newDuration, rate, 1)

Level 3 Strategic Thinking - Attempt 1 of the following:

  1. Convert the following recursively defined equation into a recursive function/algorithm
    1. f(n) = f(n-1)*2 for f(1) = 100
  2. Convert the following recursively defined equation into a recursive function/algorithm
    1. f(n) =f(n-1)+29.53 for f(0) = 125
  3. Convert the following recursively defined equation into a recursive function/algorithm
    1. f(n-1) = f(n+1)*(-1.5) for f(1) = 5

Level 4 Extended Thinking - Attempt 2 of the following

  1. Exercise 2.7.1 a) in Python not C in Foundations of Computing
  2. Exercise 2.7.8 in Foundations of Computing

  3. Take this iteratively defined function and rewrite it as recursive.

    def multiply (x,y):
        answer = 0
        for i=0 i<y:
            answer = answer+x
        return answer
  4. Take this equation and rewrite it as a recursive algorithm/function  f(x) = f(x-1)+f(x-2) for f(0)= 1, f(1) = 1

  5. Take this iteratively defined function and rewrite it as recursive.

    def power(x,n):
        p = 1
        for i = 0 i<n
            p = p*x
        return p

  6. Take this iteratively defined function and rewrite it as recursive.

    def getTotalIterative(n, total):
         while n>=0:
              print(n)
              total = total+n
              n -=1
          return total

    print(getTotalIterative(5,0))

  7. Given the following recursive function in python, code the inverse function from decimal to binary.  Your inverse function must be recursive.  In the comments identify your base case and why you chose it as well as where the recursion is. I know that this is EASILY find-able online.  If I find you copied one, you won't receive credit.  It is a small change to my code that makes this work.

    def binToDec(binary, i):
        decimal = 0
        if (binary >0):
            decimal = decimal + binary%10*2**i+binToDec(binary//10, i+1)
        return decimal

    i=binToDec(111,0)
    print(i)

Criteria for Success

You will submit attempts at all of the problems.  This is considered complete if you have successfully received .8 or higher.

Submit

Submit your work and justifications.

name: 3.12 [DO NOW] Practice: Problem Set #3 Series (1.5 hours)
description:
Practice Problems Set #3

Purpose

Tasks:

Resources for this Task

Collaboration

You MAY choose to collaborate on this task.  Below are the ways that you can collaborate

1 - Work with 1 other person to complete the entire task.  - Both of you will submit the same work.  Make sure you tell me that you worked together and let me know the most important thing that YOU contributed to the pair.

Academic Integrity

For this task, I want credit for where you got all of your answers.  If you pulled them from your brain, say that.  If you pulled them from course notes, put that.  If you pulled them from AI or the internet make sure you cite those using a link (see here how to get an appropriate permanent ChatGPT AI link).

Step #1 - Problems

Level 1 Recall - Choose 2 of the following questions:

  1. What is a series?
  2. What is a summation?

Level 2 Skill - Choose 2 of the following:

  1. Convert the following from series to summation or summation to series
  2. Convert the following from series to summation or summation to series
    2. 3+8+13+18+...+(3+5i)
  3. Convert the following from series to summation or summation to series
    1. 1*2*3+2*3*4+...+n(n+1)(n+2)
  4. Convert the following from series to summation or summation to series

Level 2 Skill - Choose 2 of the following:

  1. Expand to show the next 3 terms (n+1, n+2, n+3)
  2. Expand to show the next 3 terms (n+1, n+2, n+3)
  3. Expand to show the next 3 terms (n+1, n+2, n+3)
    2. 3+8+13+18+...+(3+5i)
  4. Expand to show the next 3 terms (n+1, n+2, n+3)
    1. 1*2*3+2*3*4+...+n(n+1)(n+2)

Level 3 Strategic Thinking - Attempt 1 of the following:

  1. Describe a strategy for converting between summation and series notation.
  2. Describe a strategy for counting on (n+1, n+2 terms) in a series and a summation.
  3. Compare and Contrast summation and product series
  4. Investigate how series and summation are used for inductive proofs.






Criteria for Success


You will submit attempts at all of the problems.  This is considered complete if you have successfully received .8 or higher.

description:

Tasks:

Resources for this Task

Collaboration

1 - Work with 1 other person to complete the entire task.  - Both of you will submit the same work.  Make sure you tell me that you worked together and let me know the most important thing that YOU contributed to the pair.

Academic Integrity

For this task, I want credit for where you got all of your answers.  If you pulled them from your brain, say that.  If you pulled them from course notes, put that.  If you pulled them from AI or the internet make sure you cite those using a link (see here how to get an appropriate permanent ChatGPT AI link).

Step #1 - Problems

Use Induction on the following problems.  Complete at least 2 of each type.  If you do more you get feedback on more of them.  The expectation is that you get at last 1 of each type correct.

Series/Summation

Complete at least 2

Divisibility

Complete at least 2

  1. is divisible by 2304 for every natural number n
  2. is divisible by 3 for integers n
  3. is divisible by 4
  4. is divisible by 11

Inequality

Complete at least 2

  1. for all integers n>2
  2. for all integers n>= 4
  3. for all natural numbers
  4. for n>=1

Criteria for Success

You will submit attempts at all of the problems.  This is considered complete if you have successfully received .8 or higher.

Each rubric area will be evaluated on the following:

  • Did they label all of the parts?  
  • Did they prove the correct base case?  
  • Do they have a hypothesis?  
  • Does it say "is true" and have the base case identified?  
  • Did they drop the sum?  
  • Did they do the inductive step of using the hypothesis?  
  • Is their algebra sound?

Submit

Submit your work and justifications.
